reviewText: Super addictive awesome roguelike. By far the best roguelike I have played in a long time.

One of the best Rougue-like games. It's very beginner friendly, and is a great example of the genre as a whole. It has a lot of depth without being overly complicated. You can actually play this game for FREE if you download it from their website. The code is publically available and will be free forever. Steam is mearly allowing people to purchase a donator version of the game. The game is easily worth the cost. And admittidly I may have accidently bought this game twice-- once on the website and once on steam.\n\n(This game has given a full wage to the game creators by donations before it went onto steam. It's that good.)

The roguelike that plays more like an RPG. Great, deep class building and turn based combat.  I dont normally like roguelikes, they seem sadisitic and needlessly opaque.  TOME avoids these issues by being complex, but fair.  It also builds a world with interesting missions and situations, plus a grognard charm in tweaking complex builds and classes.

I cannot get past level five yet, but I will. I'm drinking my milk and soon I'll hit level 6! This game is harder than Darksouls and a better story. It seems really in depth so far and I love the turn based combat. It reminds me of old school rpg games from my youth; Ultima 4, the old SSI TSR games. I reccomend this game with all of my blackened heart! Play, PLAY IT NOW!

I can't recommend this game enough!  It's got full keyboard support, so you rarely need to touch the mouse which makes moving and navigating menus much faster. There's a ton of mods if you feel the out-of-the-box experience needs a little spice.\n\nThis game is a true rogelike where every move matters and every level is preparing you for the next. You'll study each death to consider how your next run will get you a little further. With each run you get a little further and a little better.  All along the way ToME is and unforgiving, yet fair game. This game is mind-candy, not eye-candy.
Dont get fooled by the LAME graphic and arts , this game will surprise you!\n
Perfect, been playing rogue-likes alot lately and this one is by far the best out of them all, Faster then Light and Binding of Isac included

This Fracking game is infuriating.  I was all for the old throwback style.  The first game i ever played was Castle of the Winds on DoS.  The gameplay in this game is pretty much the same.  It is super fun and really interesting to try out the different classes.  I would say this game is not for everone though.  You only have so many lives before you get to trash your toon and start over from scratch.  I haven't been able to make it past lvl 15 without final dying and quitting.  There is an option to play with unlimited lives but you don't unlock classes or get achievments, so whats the point really?  I would be all for this game if it just game more lives or made things slightly easier.
This is a very good roguelike, lots of fun!

Let me tell you this game is quite enjoyable. This roguelike is truly product of dedication and love. It goes without saying that you will face many endangering encounters that will demand a plan B and C to GTFO when the situation requires it. Music consist of less than 2 minute loops of glorious and heroic soundscapes that will pump you up.  I have played Elona+, Nethack, Brogue and Adon, and, boy, this game sure has won a place in the hall of fame of my heart.
Great game, will keep you entertained for hundreds of hours.

Massive amount of content. Tons of unlockables. Great character customization. Immensely strategic turn based combat. Retro graphics. Fans of classic games like Exile and Avernum will enjoy this game immensley. Permadeth mode best of all!\n\nSo after a year of playing and almost 200 hours put into the game, I feel secure adding some more comments about the game. I can say, hands down, that this game is AMAZING! There is an unbelievable amount of content and lore that only keeps growing due to an active modding community and DLC from Dark God. I'm still discovering new, unexplored, areas of the game. I haven't even unlocked all the character creation paths yet. Best of all is the difficulty of this game. Any boss encounter will prove to be a challange, every encounter will become one if you raise the difficulty at all. One word of warning, this game is ADDICTIVE. I literally haven't been able to put it down since the DLC was released. Each class feels completely different. The only true drawback of the game is it's UI. At times the interface can be difficult. Some actions, escpecially in the inventory, take to many key strokes to accomplish. The menu hot keys are oddly selected too. Item information is displayed in a pretty hard to look at format. It seems the game's interface was designed with the keyboard in mind and not the mouse. The item filters need to be more specific. Being able to view the items based on armor type or weapon class would be handy. The hotbars get pretty confusing torwards the end of the game, when your character starts having more abilities than theres convinient room on the hotbar. Two, or more, active hotbars could alleviate this a little. It definitely takes some getting used to to become adept at interfacing with the game efficiently. Overall though, I would give this game the highest marks on content, lore, gameplay, and challenge!
The best roguelike I've ever played. Engaging combat mechanics, tons of race/class/skill combinations, and fun game modes.
Gudgud

This game is a good intro to Roguelike games. It is not punishingly difficult, and the lack of a food system allows you to go into each encounter at full strength.  You are free to explore at your own leisure and the multiple maps per location make frequent restarts ( if you are new ) more manageable.\n\nI've played the game for a little over  two years now and of all the Roguelikes I've played this is the only one i've returned too year after year for another run.  If you take the time to learn the game you will be rewarded with boss kills, blindly charging ahead will get you most deservedly killed.  Very refreshing.
My number of hours on record is deceptive since I've been playing ToME4 since its very first beta release.   Its probably closer to 400 hours.\n\nThat being said, its alright.

For those who value content over graphics, this is a fun game.  Very difficult, depending on your luck with item drops.  It can be a bit repetetive once you get in the grove of your character or if you die a lot and have to do the same zones over and over again.
Excellent Roguelike. Worth the price!
While it might not be for everyone (Aka: people who hate roguelikes) it's an awesome game.

Have you heard the saying, 'you cannot judge a book by its cover'? ToME doesn't look pretty, it's true. Far from it, actually. But if you give it a try, you'll soon realize that it's one of the best rogue-like games you have ever played.

Tales of Maj'Eyal is a rogue-like RPG that works on a turn based combat/movement system in which a hero starts his journey in the realms of 'Eyal to conquer his quests.

After that intro all I have to say about this game is that its really addictive once you get the hang of it. It's fun messing around with the good amount of builds you can make in this game and there are more characters you can unlock from completing quests and such. The game itself isnt easy, Like most rogue-likes you're going to find yourself at first struggling, asking yourself what do I do next. Fear not. You have the mighty Z button, the Z button allows you to auto-explore and find random things in the stage,Take note that the auto-explore will go through everything around the stage so be careful you might find that special enemy you don't wan't to find along the way.

Back to the game, There is a great soundtrack to the game, Which obviously helps greatly to immerse you more into the environment.
The game may look old but there is something about that art-style that is just appealing and fun to watch.

In gameplay terms you'll find yourself killed alot at first as you'll probably wonder what the hell every skill does or how to approach monsters/towns etc. But fear not there is a tutorial for the new players if they decide to take it.

The game itself has a nice character progression pattern, as in you gain levels, find gold and items/equipments that will drop or just be generater in the world you play in, this adds to the whole adventure experience and people who love loot will have a good time going through this game.

You can select different difficulties and unlike most rogue-likes you have the option to actually return to the game a few times depending on what mode you pick (obviously if you pick the harder ones once you die, you ded as hell).

Overall Tales of Maj'Eyal is a great rogue-like game and I would recommend it to anyone who's looking for a game that they can actually feel like they're playing an old school rogue-like with modern touches to it.

On another note you can try the game on the developers website for free, But i'm not sure it contains all the content of the game so I would recommend buying it if you enjoy/like it.

A fun, simple on the surface, complex on the inside role playing game.  Brings back memories of playing role playing games back in the 80s. This game does not need extravagent graphics, and it plays well on a laptop.

This is not a game for those addicted to really flashy graphics. Yes, at first they may seem a bit poor to you. I gurantee in light of the game you'll get over it.
This is in fact a very good game. I'm not very far into it during my review but I can say the fantastic diversity of class and races means the replay value is very high. (Which is good, because if you'll die)
You could play it on the death-free mode, but i'd highly reccomend against it. Those games always end up feeling worthless.
TIP: It is surprisingly easy to lose track of a battle because you're lazily skipping through and die, even to normal mobs.

This is what happens when you take roguelikes and add some modern UI conveniences, difficulty levels, and an option for a forgiving variety of permadeath. You can get it for free online, but I recommend picking it up on Steam because frankly it's worth more than 7 bucks.

If you enjoy dungeon crawlers at all, but want more meat than Nethack, this is the game for you.\n\nExcellent skill trees, fun unlockables, and very challenging game. It's a lot of fun to try different builds, and the turn-based grid-based combat is the best!
Super fun and challenging. I want to put so much more time into this. Thank you DarkGod for punishing me and enjoy the tears from the characters I've lost and the many more I will lose.

Where to even start with this game... You want magic slinging bears? Check. You want snakes that can project forcefields with their minds? Double check. This game has a wide range of enemies and items and each playthrough has always felt unique in some way. On top of this, the character customization is incredible. The player has a choice of playing as a wide range of races, and an even wider range of classes - all of which can be shaped to play just about however the player likes! My only qualms with the game would have to be that it's a bit TOO unforgiving at times (30% of the level's enemies coming at you at once, GL!) All in all, I'd say it's a 7.5/10. There's definitely room for improvement, but the game as it is is VERY entertaining.
Excellent Roguelike. Worth the price!
While it might not be for everyone (Aka: people who hate roguelikes) it's an awesome game.
Really awesome game, If you havent played it yet, its your loss.

ToME is what roguelikes should aspire to be. It's enormously complete, with tons of content, creative and an absolute bundle of fun. Although the graphics may seem primitive, the enormous, randomly generated gameworld and quests are easily going to give you a run for your money. The progression system is fair, and allows you to learn the game before giving you access to more complex, tactically challenging classes. Easily one of my favorite releases this year.
Great game.. one of the best roguelikes ever.
This is a damn good roguelike.

Absolutely yes! One of the best roguelikes i've ever played, and I've played many of them. Every character feels unique since they can be deeply customized. Part of its awesomeness stems from getting rid of those unfair deaths (lack of food, poisoned food, cursed items, out of depth monsters, undetectable deadly traps,etc) that are so frequent in other rogues (i'm looking at you stone soup), making every death your fault. steam doesn't properly track game time during offline mode, but i've played it for no less than 75 hours. I could spend the rest of my sunday trying to put into words how fascinating this game is, but unfortunately I've other issues to attend.
Amazing. Anyone with a love for roguelikes in a fantasy setting will love this.

The best game I have ever played in twenty years of computer gaming, bar none (and I have played a LOT of games). Eight years on I can still recall how profoundly that game gripped me, and I am not an overly emotional person. You will care about the characters, you will be moved, you will make choices that tell you more about yourself. It sounds trite, I know, but it really is that good. If only someone would make more of these...insightful, intelligent, devastatingly creative. Fallout is the only RPG to come close. A word of warning: You MUST read all the text, explore all the dialogue options, if you are to gain the most from the game. A decent intelligence and wisdom score is recommended.....although so is a decent score in everything else....the game does the best job of making usually superflous statistics genuinely useful that I have ever seen. Still very much worth playing.
One of the best RPGs i've played.

I'm in a love/hate relationship with this game. I suppose that's the mark of an excellently crafted roguelike. Often when I die I'll want to exclaim how that was such bull puckey, that the game is unbalanced and it was totally unfair. That there wasn't any lesson I could have learned from dying that way. Yet somehow, I find I'm slowly getting an intuition about how to play the game. I play so that each time, I can get just a little bit further. That's the thing about roguelikes. They aren't about learning to play the game, and then playing it. You can't be said to know how to play the game until you've won.\n\nFor a game I've never gotten past the first third despite having played it for over 70 hours, I can't really claim that the sameyness keeps me from playing. I don't feel stuck or feel the need to consult strategy guides; the process of learning in ToME is rewarding. It'd be awesome if levels had more variety and the worldmap was randomized, but I don't think that would make it more replayable.

reviewText:
THE best rogue-like there is. Incredible depth  for character creation with vastly different classes, races and skills.
If you like rogue-likes you will like this like nothing before, not even like your mother likes you. Like it now and it will like you right back!

11/10 would like again!

I never played any Rouge or Rouge-like games before, and this game is _dangerouly_ addictive. Despite the linear questing and story line, each time I played it with the same race and same class, I experienced different ways to advance my character. Never was I using the same game play style in any instance I played thus far as it offers enough randomess to keep you playing for hours and hours. I only played two classes right now and I learn something new on each roll.


There is no more complex and fullfilling hardcore RPG game like this!

This title surpassed all of my expectations and has left me for wanting more. Truely a compelling experience. Great Character development, and interesting combat. There is no words to describe the feeling as your character becomes more powerfull, only to suddenly have it all end violently.  This game does not like you, and will break you if you're not paying attention.

Perma-Death at it's finest....

No regrets my friends! Once more into the breach!!

You know, I was hesitent about buying this game... and BOY DID IT PROVE ME WRONG. Very addicting, sooooo much content. Meaty portion of lore, lots of character customization, challenging tactical combat. This roguelike is the real deal.\nENVOY RATED: 9/10

I've played quite a few roguelikes, and ToME sets a new standard.  There's a tremendous amount of depth, both in character/skill customization and equipment buildouts. Custom tileset support, modding, and access to the underlying game engine just happen to be gravy.  Plus, Linux!

One of the most entertaining and well done rogue-likes I've played in a long time. The UI is understandable, there's tooltips for pretty much everything - In essence everything missing from a lot of rogue-likes. And that is just the shinies - The game itself is very deep as well.

There's a very well made 'story' mode (it is HARD the first 100 times you try :)) and you will quickly unlock the regular rogue-like endless dungeon (which can also be accessed by a story-mode character once you've completed the story).

There's tons of races and classes, a lot of which needs to be unlocked from playing the story - They classes play very differently, with huge scope for customization, so almost endless replayability.

I could go on - This is probably one of my most played games of all time - If you have ANY love for rogue-likes - Or looking to try one that is easy to get into - this is the game for you.

You will die. You will probably die a lot. With that said, the game is honestly quite fun and almost entirely fair. Fairness in a Roguelike is, of course, a bit subjective, but you will very rarely run into dead before you know what hit you situations. For those of you who aren't into the One Life to Live" concept of Roguelikes
date: there is a mode that lets you have extra lives at set points so that dire badger isn't the end of your career.\n\nThe classes are varied and each have their unique flair
recommended: transparency in mobs is pretty great even though there'll still be a learning curve here or there and it has a ridiculous amount of achievements for those who thrive on that."

reviewText: Addictive game.  Extremely replayable
Hot diggity dang, the best roguelike out there.\nAlso available for free from te4.org

Take a roguelike and a modern game, put them together in a blender, and what do you get? ToME: Classic turn-based fantasy mixed with modern features such as highly impressive graphical effects, achievements, content unlocking, etc.

While it doesn't go beyond the usual set of boring fantasy races, it DOES have a massive selection of classes that act in extremely different ways to each other. Even the default fighter (called a Bulwark) isn't even close to the usual bump until it dies" fighter of other roguelikes.

Even if you're new to the genre
date: ToME can be a good way to get yourself in with optional lower difficulties. If you're an old hand
recommended: the variety of classes and the optional higher difficulties can still give you a challenge.\n\nEven though the game is free on te4.org
hoursPlayed: $8 is a complete steal for a game with this much replay value."

reviewText: Super addictive awesome roguelike. By far the best roguelike I have played in a long time.

One of the best Rougue-like games. It's very beginner friendly, and is a great example of the genre as a whole. It has a lot of depth without being overly complicated. You can actually play this game for FREE if you download it from their website. The code is publically available and will be free forever. Steam is mearly allowing people to purchase a donator version of the game. The game is easily worth the cost. And admittidly I may have accidently bought this game twice-- once on the website and once on steam.\n\n(This game has given a full wage to the game creators by donations before it went onto steam. It's that good.)

The roguelike that plays more like an RPG. Great, deep class building and turn based combat.  I dont normally like roguelikes, they seem sadisitic and needlessly opaque.  TOME avoids these issues by being complex, but fair.  It also builds a world with interesting missions and situations, plus a grognard charm in tweaking complex builds and classes.

Would recommend it to any roguelike fan, but if youre even slightly less hardcore than that then you'll drop this game instantly cause it bears all of the default roguelike flaws like poor balancing of classes (some of them faceroll, some of them hard to survive even on the low lvls), playing boring first lvls over and over again, cause the exploration part is pure trial and error, you can easily get to impossible to beat encounter without any warning, faceroll locations with bosses that will oneshot you, pretty hard locations with bosses which easier than regular monsters (i guess it's overall poor balance and design). If you don't mind all of the above, then it's pretty nice game you can enjoy.

Very deep yet easily accessable turnbased roguelike. With a butt-load of options, settings, mods, GUIs, this game is perfect for jumping into and easy to stay in. And with different races and classes to unlock, over a thousand items, armor, weapons, achievements, on top of the lore and stories that Maj' Eyal can tell. What more could you ask for?

People Who'd Like This Game: RPG/Roguelike Fans
Why?: Great interface that is fully customizable with hotbars and maps, deep character building and number padding, but not too much as to overwhelm.

People Who'd Hate This Game: Simple-Minded RPG/Button Masher Fans
Why?: Can be confusing to understand what you are looking at if you aren't a fan of RPG's, or would prefer being dropped into the action/powerfulness that you would be too bored/confused to do alone.

After 20+ hours on this game, I still haven't managed to get through all the second set of dungeons.
This game is brutally hard...but every time you die, you realize it typically is because of your own incapability, or cockiness that gets you there.

And that is what makes this such a great game.  So many options for building a character, and a lot of crazy ways to die.  They most likely will come from you just trying to explore the game world and stumbling upon something you had no business messing with at the time.

Every single time I've died, it just makes me more revved up to try to beat it my next go around.
If you're a bit of a masochist, and love rogue-likes, you gotta give this game a try!
Super in depth rogue-like with many class/race combinations and tons of abilites, very fun game.

A simple but additive rogue-like, with loot and unlocks and lots and lots of stats. Steam Workshop and DLC mean you'll never run out of new material. All this is great, but the crowning acheivement is the music. A triumphant soundtrack that can make flipping through inventory feel heroic.

In my opinion it's the best rouge-like ever.
1) It doesn't look as bad as you think it would do, altough there is an ASCII mode of graphics.
2) It can be run on anything, even on toasters and concrete blocks.
3) It has a huge selection and variety of classes and races to choose from.
4) The looting system and the inventory system are well done and it feels good to loot stuff.
5) It has a nice learning curve, not a cliff as it is in most of the rouge-like games.

And the list goes on and on. I could write a whole essay why this game is a masterpiece, but I won't since I don't want to spoil the fun.

You should definitely buy it.
I've been playing this game for awhile before it came out here. It's the best roguelike I've ever played.
One of the better roguelikes I've played recently, it's on my Like" list."
Years of replay value.

A wonderful roguelike! The food clock and challenge of identifying potions and scrolls has been replaced with a focus on tactical combat and powers triggered by a hot bar on the bottom of the screen. The game forces you to get into tough battles and have to really think about your actions to progress.

The classes (there are plenty of them) are a varied and interesting. The skill trees are intricate and forgiving by allowing you to respec the most recent points spent. There seem to be a good variety of builds of each type of class.

So far I've only made it to the mid-game with one of the fighter/mage hybrids. I was sent on quests, entered a handful of dungeons and had a really good time.

So far, as of December 2013, this is by far the best roguelike available on Steam. The only games for me that come close to this are NetHack, ADOM (coming to Steam soon) and Brogue (free). A big thumbs up.

The only negative review for this game is get Dungeons Of Dredmore. A good choice for an alternate, I recommend you get that game also. I've been told this game is open source and you can get it for free also, but after playing it I would have just donated that amount anyway. This is a good solid game that looks like a mix between Ragnarok(also freeware but you might need dosbox to play) and Din's curse. This and ragnarok are two of the most true to form roguelikes I can think of as most have you go level to level with creatures at the same equivilent level to fight. in TOME you can blunder into a dungeon that is way to hard for your level or have just a random monster(s) in a vault that is way beyond your means. The only real complaint I might have at this point is sometime you can get killed by a creature offscreen and can do nothing about it(like Xcom). Of course I just take this as meaning I have to get better!! buy it and good luck, you'll need it!!!!

This game is totally awesome.  Look at some videos, and if this kind of game appeals to you, then buy it.  It is a total steal at the asking price.  The only downside is the lower production values, but you can over-look that for a totally awesome rouge-like game.
A great modern roguelike RPG. Definitely worth more than they ask for it.

If you want to get started on the roguelike genre, then this game is the one to start at. Unlike others, this one will allow you to change the difficulty level during character creation, so both new players and veterans won't feel forced to choose one or the other. This game also features a great deal of races and classes, most of which you have to unlock through gameplay, increasing greatly its replayability. The best thing about this roguelike, without a doubt is the lore, as it is really rich in detail and quite interesting.\nFans of roguelikes, buy this game, you won't regret it.

While this game does have a learning curve the guides that have been posted will soon take care of that. You have to remember that this game is a roguelike and you don't need to act quickly, a little time spent looking over your options usually can get you out of a sticky situation. The quality of the game is superb and the gameplay great. This game is just what I want in a roguelike.

While ToME is technically free if you go to the website (and I encourage you to check it out there to make sure it is a game you enjoy), I am glad I paid the Steam price. It essentially counts the same as if you are a donator on the official web site, giving you the same benefits they get.

As for the game itself, it is a roguelike. That means randomly generated dungeons, items, monsters, etc... and permanent death. ToME actually has an optional mode where you get multiple lives also, in case you are new to roguelikes and want to ease into things. What ToME does that stands out from the rest is have a very interesting class and race system, which is very customizable to your taste. For example, as a Rogue you can choose to specialize in stealthy gameplay with devastating sneak attacks, deadly traps, or a brawling play style with dirty fighting techniques that give you the advantage when facing foes. The choice is yours, and in addition to stats, each race gives a pool of 4 unique abilities you can also choose to train up, making different race and class combinations play somewhat differently.

Another feature of ToME that I don't normally see is an overworld system. After clearing your introduction dungeon you'll be thrust out into the open world, free to explore and attempt to clear dangerous forests, dungeons, and hideouts of foes. It makes the game feel large, like your adventures are part of the world of Maj'Eyal and not just isolated to a single deep dungeon.

Finally, ToME is extremely mod-friendly. Don't want to unlock all the classes and races yourself? There is a mod for that. There are mods for new items, new classes, new dungeons, etc... You name it.

I am not yet very far into the game, but I have no reservations recommending it, especially giving it a try for free on their website: http://te4.org.

This is, as of the end of 2013, my favorite Roguelike to date. I've really enjoyed things like Dungeons of Dredmor and Dungeons of the Endless but this one takes the cake. It has a much more varied world, a very complex leveling and progression system, and a multitude of races and classes to play as. The best way I can describe this would be as a D&D Roguelike (though it isn't D&D, it has that insane level choices and progression). The game has been out for several years, though it is new to steam, and the Devs are still releasing free content updates to this day. If you want a new roguelike, and one that you won't tire of quickly, check this one out.

This game blew my mind! It's an RPG Pearl like Dark Sun Shattered Lands. You don't controll a party though but it has so many classes you can unlock and play, it's insane. Re-playability is big, the dungeons feel different every time. And it's hard as hell ( u can play with infinite lives if you like, just to unlock everything if you like) !!! I really recommend it!

Great roguelike. Lots of classes and races for a wide variety of play. The skill systems are complex and require a lot of thought in order to build a character that is capable of beating the game. Just really fun and highly suggested. I played the free version for a while but I'm glad to finally pay for it; certainly worth more than $7.

Its $7 and its THE BEST roguelike dungeon crawler. It makes you think and use strategy to survive instead of just hack n slash.

Quests are awesome and have good stories. Good amount of random and needed loot. Bosses are actually hard and take planning to kill but can be done. Plenty of replayability.

Its $7...
Best rogue-like game I've ever played.
I have played and loved this game for MANY years, it is an absolute joy.

Brilliant, the fact that a freeware game developed by one person has more customization and diversity than any multi-million dollar game I have ever played is mind boggling. To reiterate a free roguelike with myriad classes/builds (more being added regularly) and some theory craft for the price tag of 0.00$,
My number of hours on record is deceptive since I've been playing ToME4 since its very first beta release.   Its probably closer to 400 hours.\n\nThat being said, its alright.
One of the very best traditional roguelikes you will find.

A game for anyone who likes rogue-like games. Just as addictive as the old style games but with one downside: Every item you find is identified for you and a mouse-over reveals strengths and weaknesses of visible enemys.\n\nI played nearly all of the rogue-style games and this one is enjoyable and a wonderful waste of time.

A really solid game. Turnbased roguelike style RPG, random loot, somewhat random monsters and a slew of classes and races to play around with. Also you can get it free here http://te4.org/download and carry over any progress to the steam version if you choose to buy it later.

You can choose if you want to play with a single life, multiple lives (getting more as you level) or infinite lives (if you're a chump). It's easy enough to die if you're not sure what you're doing or get in over your head but most deaths feel fair, with the rare RNG reaming thrown in.

There's a fair few classes to choose from (easily 20-25), ranging from your typical sword and board fighter or fireball slinging mage to disease spewing filthmancers or combination time-mage fighters, though many of the more interesting classes need to be unlocked. A bit of exploring will get you most classes, with some being a bit harder to find. There's also 8 or so races, each with their own advantages and disadvantages, and it's easy to bounce back from each death with a new character or a new build in mind.

This game's a great timesink, it's easy to get into and do decently well without knowing half of what anything means or does and the developer's very active, with new updates being fairly frequent.

Would recommend it to any roguelike fan, but if youre even slightly less hardcore than that then you'll drop this game instantly cause it bears all of the default roguelike flaws like poor balancing of classes (some of them faceroll, some of them hard to survive even on the low lvls), playing boring first lvls over and over again, cause the exploration part is pure trial and error, you can easily get to impossible to beat encounter without any warning, faceroll locations with bosses that will oneshot you, pretty hard locations with bosses which easier than regular monsters (i guess it's overall poor balance and design). If you don't mind all of the above, then it's pretty nice game you can enjoy.

Very deep yet easily accessable turnbased roguelike. With a butt-load of options, settings, mods, GUIs, this game is perfect for jumping into and easy to stay in. And with different races and classes to unlock, over a thousand items, armor, weapons, achievements, on top of the lore and stories that Maj' Eyal can tell. What more could you ask for?

People Who'd Like This Game: RPG/Roguelike Fans
Why?: Great interface that is fully customizable with hotbars and maps, deep character building and number padding, but not too much as to overwhelm.

People Who'd Hate This Game: Simple-Minded RPG/Button Masher Fans
Why?: Can be confusing to understand what you are looking at if you aren't a fan of RPG's, or would prefer being dropped into the action/powerfulness that you would be too bored/confused to do alone.

reviewText:
I've been playing this game in its various incarnations since it was PernAngband in the 1990s, then Troubles of MIddle Earth, and now finally Tales of Maj'Eyal - free from copyright infringement and better than ever!

It's truly exceptional, and these days, comes with so many lovely enhancements that Roguelikes have traditionally lacked. Mouse control, skill hotkeys, unlockables and stat tracking, and global chat with other playters, MMO-style, in the game window.

Underneath all this is a game system that is elegant, varied, and will keep you occupied for hours upon hours upon hours. Each character plays differently and has a host of interesting skill trees to work through. The dungeons are randomly generated, of course, but within some boundaries that ensure that each has its own flavour and unique style.

Death is permanent, as with all roguelikes (although there is another little helping hand in Adventure" mode which gives you a few extra lives to play with) but whenever I lose a character it's never a crushing blow - because now I get to enjoy starting over with a brand new one.

You can download this game for free from te4.org but it's well worth a fiver to support DarkGod and help him keep updating this brilliant title."

A really impressive turn based roguelike with randomly generated quests, maps, and just about everything else. I have yet to dig more deeply into this game but I can tell its very good and has a whole lot of depth to it.

Great game. I purchased it because it's cheap and to pass the time till some games I'm waiting for come out, and I am completely addicted.

The value for what you are paying is huge. If you are, or ever have been a fan of Roguelike games you MUST have this game. It is very deep, but is newb friendly. You do NOT need to know the details of the game in order to get started or to enjoy it.

I'm glad Steam picked this up, I wouldn't have found it otherwise.

A lot of stuff to read in the first hour or so, but the gameplay is fun. The more you play and read/know about rules, items and the game in general, the better it gets. This is a tiny investment for a game that has the potential to outlast many other roguelikes I've acquired on Steam (look at my games inventory to know which titles I refer to). If you're looking for a roguelike, prefer this over the others. It's definitely the deepest of them with actual RPG rules, not just shallow click-fest rules.

A bit difficult at the start but very addictiing and fun to play! I think this one is one of the best roguelike-games here in Steam! And for those who want to class diversities, this game is for you as it holds a lot of different classes and different races that can be unlocked as you progress through the game.

What's more fun to this game is that you can choose modes which has permadeath and non-permadeath, meaning, you can choose either to explore the game or to challenge yourself!

Buy it now!

Ah, an old favorite of mine. It's good that it's finally come to Steam. The easiest way to describe Tales of Maj'Eyal would be to say that it's a roguelike in the classical sense done right, but for every feature that serves only as a refinement of the genre, there are twenty genuinely original ideas that help this game become so much more than meets the eye. Like any game in the genre, you won't enjoy it at first. It'll phase between confusing and boring for a while, but when you get the hang of it and things pick up, you'll forget there ever was a world outside of Maj'Eyal.
This game looks so simple, but it's really awesome.\nNot even sure how I got so addicted to this game.\nI guess I have a soft spot for drunken dwarf berserkers.
Hot diggity dang, the best roguelike out there.\nAlso available for free from te4.org

Take a roguelike and a modern game, put them together in a blender, and what do you get? ToME: Classic turn-based fantasy mixed with modern features such as highly impressive graphical effects, achievements, content unlocking, etc.

While it doesn't go beyond the usual set of boring fantasy races, it DOES have a massive selection of classes that act in extremely different ways to each other. Even the default fighter (called a Bulwark) isn't even close to the usual bump until it dies" fighter of other roguelikes.

Even if you're new to the genre
date: ToME can be a good way to get yourself in with optional lower difficulties. If you're an old hand
recommended: the variety of classes and the optional higher difficulties can still give you a challenge.\n\nEven though the game is free on te4.org
hoursPlayed: $8 is a complete steal for a game with this much replay value."

TOME avoids these issues by being complex, but fair.  It also builds a world with interesting missions and situations, plus a grognard charm in tweaking complex builds and classes.

And the fact that you slowly unlock classes as you play is brilliant.  Now I know why this won rogue-like of the year a few times in a row.  Buy it because these games need the support!"

Tales of Maj'Eyal is for those of us who cannot say no to a challenge. The combat mechanics is very intricate and there are thousands of combinations. There are many classes and races to choose from. Each class is sculpted in such a way that no one class will feel the same as the other. There's also an amazing and rich lore behind the game that you find as you explore its many dungeons.\n\nIf you are into roguelikes or just want a challenge, then this is definitely one game you won't want to miss!

Tales of Maj'Eyal is a fantastic roguelike. As a roguelike its simple to learn and also have complexity. A skill system akin to Diablo 2 allows unique character builds within classes. Skills have cooldowns, this works very well in the turn based structure especially combined with effects that effect cooldown time. Inventory management is simple to use and relatively limited item slots create thoughtful decisions. As a long term player of roguelikes I highly recommend Tales of Maj'Eyal to beginners and roguelike veterans alike.

I love this game!  ToME is probably my most-played game of the last year or so, and for good reason.  It is challenging and rewards sound strategy.  The mythology is rich and ever-growing, and the community that has sprung up around the game is the sort of environment that fosters cooperation and creativity.  Thank you, DarkGod, for making this game so rewarding!

Tales of Maj'Eyal is a very rewarding Roguelike game.  Before you buy the game, though, you should consider whether the Roguelike genre appeals to you because this game is not a typical dungeon crawling RPG like Diablo II.  It seems that most of the negative reviews for this game have come from players who failed to consider their purchase.

The basic premise of a Roguelike game is randomly or semi-randomly generated dungeons with randomly generated monsters and randomly generated loot.  Luck is an integral part of the Roguelike genre, and most of them allow you only one life.  Skilled players can work with what they're given to create a powerful character, and get through very challenging randomly generated rooms/bosses/dungeons/etc.  Less skilled players might find that they die.  Often.  Tales of Maj'Eyal is unusually 'fair' for a Roguelike game, but you shouldn't mistake that to mean that it's easy, because it isn't easy at all.  It gives you extra lives, and most of the time the monsters are beatable for your level (even if they say that they're a much higher level).  The game even warns you when you're about to open a special room (rooms that often times have very numerous and/or difficult and/or high level monsters) or treasure chest (which usually spawns enemies).  Occasionally you'll run into a very difficult pack of mobs or a difficult boss, and if you lose all of your lives, then you die.  That's life, and that's how the Roguelike genre works.  Hopefully you unlocked something to explore for your next playthrough.

The appeal of this game is that there is a LOT of stuff to unlock.  You'll find yourself accidentally unlocking new classes, races, and even game modes all the time, unless you're using an unlockables guide, in which case you probably aren't having as much fun as you could be having!  There's also a great amount of class diversity, tons of classes, and even lots of depth within each class.  As a bonus, the game features a really cool world to explore and learn about.  There isn't so much of a 'storyline' but there is really a lot of lore to learn, and there are many things to discover about the current shape of the world, past events, and even letters and such from random adventurers or random people that give insight on a particular dungeon or event.  If you're anything like me, then you'll love that part of the game, but if you're one of those people who never read anything in a game, ever, then that's fine too because you can easily skip lore popups and keep playing.  If these things sound appealing to you, then great, you'll love the game.  If the Roguelike premise doesn't sound very appealing, then you may want to look elsewhere, but don't buy the game and then make a negative review if you can't even get past the first level (also here's a tip: don't play a Shalore on your first playthrough because they have a very difficult starting zone... I suspect that people who found the first level to be 'impossible' probably played a Shalore).

The UI definitely has its shortcomings, which is probably the worst thing about the game, but all-in-all I think it's a very impressive game for having been designed by one person, and well worth your 7 dollars to buy.  Also you can play it for free at te4.org, so if you're on the fence about whether to purchase it, feel free to play for, well, free.
This game is balls out badass\nget on it
This is a Good Game.

This is one of the greatest roguelikes I ever played. The story is beautiful with a rich backstory and  there are many classes and races to choose from. There is no grinding and each location has its own flavour and story. Also the game is very replayable and by solving quests you can unlock extra races, classes or features which you can use in other games.

In contrast with other roguelikes I've played, this one provides surprisingly good graphics and controls.

The game is continuously updated, each update bringing new content.

A must buy for any roguelike fan.

P.S. It reminded me of Valhalla, an old DOS game I used to play. Perhaps alchemy could be included in a future release.

Perfect mix of roguelike combat with RPG customization when it comes to items and skills. Each class has an origin story and you unlock further classes in the game as you encounter various events in the world. It's a bit different than traditional roguelikes as you're not descening one specific dungeon for a huge number of levels, but rather you play on an overworld map that has hundreds of different areas to explore.\n\nDefinitely recommend it for anyone looking for a turn-based experience custom-tailored to your preferences.
One of the most finely-crafted modern roguelikes around.

Tales of Maj'Eyal is an extremely difficult, yet rewarding roguelike. It doesn't matter if you're only a few minutes in, or a few hours in--one misplaced attack or brash move can mean the end of your character, I constantly find myself back at the character creation screen, rolling a new character to try and see how far I can get... it's pretty difficult if you don't understand the mechanics of turn-based roguelikes (I'm fairly new to the genre). What draws me most to this game, honestly, is the depth of customization. Insane amounts of gear, unique skill trees to each talent archetype [20+ different categories (each 5 deep)], and the ultimate consequence of perma-death keep me playing this game. While I'm not really a fan of lore, I can definitely appreciate how much effort the developers put into creating a real atmosphere and background for the game. The tone, to me, is dark, dank... dramatic, and dire; just reading the class descriptions gives one a real sense of purpose for each character. If you're reading this during the weekend deal of March, 2013 - get this game. Even if not, $6.99 is a steal regardless, provided you're a fan of this genre. If you're the action-y type, this game probably isn't for you. If you're a tactician, and like having total control over damn-near every aspect of your character and his fate, then ToME is for you.

Great rogue-like game with (currently) 5 difficulty settings and 3 death settings (ex. Permadeath, limited lives, or unlimited lives) which allow you to play at the pace you desire.\n\nThere are a large number of classes with different playstyles and customizable builds on each, which gives great replayability.

It took me a little while to get into It but I've really liked this one

After 20+ hours on this game, I still haven't managed to get through all the second set of dungeons.
This game is brutally hard...but every time you die, you realize it typically is because of your own incapability, or cockiness that gets you there.

And that is what makes this such a great game.  So many options for building a character, and a lot of crazy ways to die.  They most likely will come from you just trying to explore the game world and stumbling upon something you had no business messing with at the time.

Every single time I've died, it just makes me more revved up to try to beat it my next go around.
If you're a bit of a masochist, and love rogue-likes, you gotta give this game a try!

I've only had this game for a few days, and it is utterly enthralling and fantastic so far. I've truly been blown away by the quality of the experience ToME offers, as you can see by the crazy amount of time I've spent after only a few days of owning it.

ToME manages to stay incredibly faithful to the roguelike genre, offering the big three parts (turn based gameplay, randomized maps, and permanent death) but providing it in a way much more relevant to today's gamers; there are varying levels of difficulty, allowing you to play with extra lives or turn off permadeath (at the cost of not being able to earn achievements or upload your character to the server to show off) and it comes pre-loaded with a beautiful graphics pack so you needn't play in ASCII if you'd rather not.

The amount of content in the game is fantastic and the randomization handled well to provide excellent replayability and a truly enjoyable experience; it can also be tuned to provide that insanely grueling challenge that Rogue and Dwarf Fortress survivors like to call Fun."

If you're a fan of the genre at all (or have been interested in the past and have been turned off by some of the more hardcore features)
date: I find myself unable to provide eloquent enough words to praise this game's virtues- get it! One of the best games I've ever played."

Tales of Maj'Eyal is an amazing roguelike with a very nice tileset. You choose from a variety of races and a variety of classes, and even more can be unlocked of each. Depending on your race and/or class, you'll start out in a specific Zone(or dungeon if you'd like). Once you finish that Zone, or before, you can return the World Map, in which you can explore it looking for more dungeons, or look for towns in which you can purchase items or find quests.

This isn't like The Elder Scrolls, where most of the game is scaled to your level or ability, each Zone has a certain difficulty, and until you're more familiar with how difficult each one is, it's better to follow the quest log. It's true that with very careful and skillful management of your spells and/techniques that you can finish a Zone that's a bit higher than you level, but there's a limit that's very quickly reached.

Each of the Zones layouts are randomly generated, though they always have the same theme(forest, cave, dungeon, etc.). However, the World Map is mostly static, meaning it doesn't shift too much between games. There are 4 main towns in the beginning for instance, 3 of them having 2 beginner Zones right next to them. These 4, and their Zones, are always in the same spot. While there are a couple more Zones that are found in the same spot, the location of all the other Zones(mostly the 'side' ones) shifts around the map between games

For the actual skills you use, they're divided up into 2 categories: Class and Generic. Class skills are like they sound: each Class has many skill trees with for skills in each, and it's up to you how you want to level them, though some trees have a level requirement. Then there's Generic. This category is mostly the same between Classes, however some Classes add an extra Generic tree or 2. Many Races also have extra Generic trees, though Races with buffs or extra trees are of course balanced in other ways.

Each Race has different bonuses and penalties to their stats, health, and experience rate, along with their Race Specific Generic Trees. So obviously some Races will be better suited to certain play styles. While some races and classes cannot be used together for Story/lore reasons, all class/race combinations are viable throughout the game, though you may need to play a bit smarter in some cases. One last thing about races: While they all have bonuses and penalties, the 'Cornac Human' is the exception in that it has no bonuses, no extra Generic Trees, and no penalties of any sort, and I recommend that if you want to try a new class but don't know what to expect, the 'Cornac Human' is a good default choice. Oh wait, Cornacs start with 1 category point, as some categories need to be unlocked with a point before you can start investing in it's skills, You can also just use the Category Point to give yourself an extra Infusion/Rune Slot, I'll talk more of this later.

As for items, they are Armor, Weapons, Jewellery, Tools, and Infusions/Runes. All items except Infusions/Runes are randomly generated for the most part, the exception being Legendary/Unique items, which are always the same, but have very unique bonuses and sometimes penalties. They sometimes even give you a skill(with a cooldown), though Tools always give a skill while they are worn.

Infusions/Runes are items which will pretty much let you 'equip' a skill, such as Healing, Regen, etc. You only have so many slots though. All classes and races, no matter the combination, start with 3 slots. When you get a Category point every 5 levels(or first if you're a Cornac), you can opt to use it to give you an extra slot. If you try to use an Infusion/Rune when all slots are filled, you'll be asked if you want to replace a currently equipped Infusion/Rune. If you do so, you do NOT get it back.

I'll cut the review short here, else I'll waffle all day. I definitely recommend this game for any roguelike and/or RPG fan. Please keep in mind that there is a free version on their site. This version is the paid version, in which it gives you an item vault(that must be reached through a semi-difficult dungeon) with a few slots to transfer items or store them between characters. The paid version also has an extra class to play with, along with an extra mode. The extra class I won't name as it changes. The most recently added class is for the paid version only. When a new one is added, the previous one becomes free. The extra game mode is 'Exploration', which is the same as normal, but gives you unlimited lives.

Please note that the DLC listed below is not a part of the free version, though they can also be purchased on their and played in the DRM free version.
Unbeleivable fun and extremely brutal. If you like challenge to your games and actually know what a Roguelike is then this is one of if not the best.

Wonderful, addictive roguelike. I'm 50 hours in and just scratching the surface. I recommend you find and install the 'old rpg' tileset if like me you prefer the look of SNES for your RPGs. Sure, you can get this for free off dude's site, but why not do the right thing, drop a couple bucks, and get Steam integration?
Extremely deep and probably one of the few games around that deserves the rogue-like" tag. The graphics + GUI may look simplistic from the screenshots (and yeah

recommended: you'll most likely enjoy this game."

Verdict: Ok game, for what it tries to be.

ToME is all about character-building and fantasy combat. It delivers well enough on the first account, with interesting choises and hard priorities. The combat soon becomes repetitive, but it's ok until it gets booring.

ToME does not deliver an enganging story, personalities or anything of interest beyond combat and character-building. Nor does it attempt to.

The single best paid roguelike I've ever had the pleasure of playing.

It's incredibly addicting, it offers a variety of unlockable content (races, classes, sub-classes, skill trees, even questlines), it caters to different playing styles, it comes with a nice tileset (and the option to 'downgrade' the visuals to ascii), a great soundtrack, an overworld with towns and shops, an intriguing storyline and lore and full mouse support.

The combat system is skill and cooldown based so it might even be appealing for RL beginners that played modern RPGs before.

Keep in mind that you can download this game for free on the dev's website - although buying it on Steam will grant you all the bonuses that a voluntary donator would get.

One of the Better games of this type on Steam. It's not pretty but you can get other tilesets for it and the Steam Workshop is full of good mod's to tweak the gameplay. Speaking of the gameplay,It's deep! the amount of race's,class,skills,item's etc. (some are un-locked after playing game) are just huge, It has a story!  You can get it for free on website but the small price you pay on Steam is worth the items you get and your putting some loot in DarkGod's hands. Over all I'm happy that I picked this up, I't has more replay to it than AAA games like Skyrim.\n\n9/10 Good Game at a Crazy low Price.

Best rogue-like game I've ever played. Extremely addictive, deep, varied, and challenging but fair with a ridiculous amount of unlockable races and classes.  Start with a melee class for an easier time and for the love of God, DO NOT reactivate the golem Atamathon unless you want a quick end to your run.
First review I've felt compelled to write. Very in depth game, very entertaining to fans of the genre and often very unforgiving if you try to run before you can walk.\n\nHighly recommended.

The term 'Rogue-like' gets tossed around alot these days, however most games that are listed in this category aren't really like Rogue at all. This game is THE exception.

If you ever played NetHack, uMoria, Rogue, or any other classic Rogue-likes, you must purchase this game. As you can see from my collected play time, it has eaten a significant chunk of my life (literally my most highly played game).

I regularly buy both indie and AAA games, and this is, by far, the most fun I've had on Steam (well...except for maybe FTL).

Potential Positives:
+ Turn based world - Monsters move when you move. Take your time.
+ Not for the faint of heart - Remember when games used to be hard? So does this developer.
+ Unlockable races and classes - Replayability, anyone?
+ Dungeons combine randomness with structure - Key elements are always there, but many elements change between adventures.
+ The price is super low - You could buy this game 8 or 9 times for the price of one AAA game.
+ Active development - Last update was about 2 weeks before this review.

Potential Negatives:
- You're going to die - a lot. Some frustration will be had.
- Graphics are nothing special, although it does come in old-school @ style display (which I use).
- Not the best music, put on your favorite album instead.

TL;DR: A rich, impressive Rogue-like for fans of old-school games (no CoD 'bros' need apply).
A great modern rogue-like that contains loads of compelling gameplay and just keeps on expanding.

Must... put.... down... mouse... long enough to sleep, eat.

This is by far one of the most addictiove games I have played in a log time. And it's hard, very hard.

Okay, so its a roguelike. But it has options to make it less unforgiving, up to a mode where you can just play en die and respawn untill you have enough. So, the casual player is catered to. Then there's a mode where you have limited lives - you can respawn, but only a few times. And of course the real roguelike - one life. Die, you're out of luck.

It's huge. I have been playing for hours and hours and so far have only made it to the 'second half' of the game twice. I am estimating that running a single game end-to-end will take you at least 4-6 hours. Though, I moght be a slowpoke - perhaps better, more experienced players can do it in a few hours less.

It's got possibilities. Like, there are so many ways to develop a character. So far I have been fiddling around with one class to see what get's me farther and farther into the game and that is working. You play, you die. Think, why did I die? Adapt in the next character.

It has a very smart way of lulling you into a false sense of security by allowing you to kill most critters on your path, then hit you from behind with some nasty rare radom boss.

There is mods out the various orifices too - enou8gh to adapt is to a format you like better.

Oh, I'd also like to add that there is a massive fanbase on the formums where the (I do believe it's one guy?) developer DarkGod hangs out too - and he actually posts, listens and helps out when you are in trouble.

Trust me - if you are into roguelikes or like fiddling around for aeons with character builds, this is something you want.
If you are not the masochistic type, it has ways of lettign you in gently and be much more forgiving.

I never played any Rouge or Rouge-like games before, and this game is _dangerouly_ addictive. Despite the linear questing and story line, each time I played it with the same race and same class, I experienced different ways to advance my character. Never was I using the same game play style in any instance I played thus far as it offers enough randomess to keep you playing for hours and hours. I only played two classes right now and I learn something new on each roll.


There is no more complex and fullfilling hardcore RPG game like this!
Looking for a game to lose hours upon hours with?  Well, here's TOME.  Say goodbye to everything you know about real life.

This game is the most rewarding roguelike I've played in quite some time.  It combines many beautifully nostalgic concepts from rpgs from the good old days.  Talents and feats" and stats will all be very familiar to the bearded rpg appreciators and  can be picked up quickly by any newcomers that might happen upon this game. date: and since the game is true to the turn-based concept
recommended: you can truly play at your own pace.\n\nThis game comes closest to the feel of that old game I spent so many hours on back in the days of "shareware"
hoursPlayed: Castle of the Winds.  I personally have been looking for a game that brought that wholesome turn-based
helpfulPercent: fuzzy feeling in my gutty wuts for the better part of two decades

votesFunny: and I don't think I'd enjoy the game more without having to earn the unlocks.  Get the DLC.\n\nI can't recommend this game highly enough.  Pour in the hours.  Keep em coming.  Drink deep.  This is a gem."

I love Rogue-like games. I played ADOM way back in 2000 to death (took me around a month of almost continuous gaming  with constant reference to games guides to finish it once).

TOME has many that endear rogue-like to people: a tough difficulty level, a range of classes, a range of races, a customisable tree, a high complexity.

It also brings with it some features that the internet world likes: regular updation (even long after Version 1), a very dedicated creator, modding and a very active community.
There are also some very interesting connected features in the game.

Notes:

1.
The graphics are not mind-blowing (though much better than the regular rogue-likes like Nethack, and the old ADOM). This is a game where your imagination is paramount. If you are very focused on graphics, then do not buy this.

2.
Steam does not show hours on this since I bought it from the original website, and got a Steam key much later when it got listed here.

Tales of Maj'Eyal is simply an amazing game.  It does an excellent job of providing everything that makes a roguelike great in a format that is extremely accessible both for hardcore fans of the genre as well as more casual players looking to get their feet wet.  The sheer amount of content in this game is incredible.  The storyline and lore are deep and enjoyable while the gameplay, particularly the combat, remain consistently engaging.

Tales of Maj'Eyal does a good job of easing a new player into the world and game mechanics by restricting the initial race and class offerings and expands outward with a number of persistent unlockables including new races, classes, and items that will become available to your future characters as you progress forward through additional sessions.  The distinct classes (particularly with different race pairings) provide tremendously distinct play styles that will keep you on your toes and force you to adjust your gameplay to find success.

To sum this up simply:  This game is outstanding, anyone with even the most remote interest would do well to pick it up, it won't let you down (and in all likelihood will keep you playing and having fun for an exceptionally long time to come).
Best Rogue-like RPG in Steam

A very solid roguelike. It's been a staple of any roguelike fans for several years and is great to see it brought to Steam where it has really made the most of unlockable/achievements and workshop to make it even easier to get some of the many great mods for it.

It has several notable changes from other roguelikes, foremost it's abilities system use a variety of different resources and are mostly about managing cooldowns. There's no health/mana pot chugging here which takes some of the tedium away from stacking potions to thinking about which abilities to use when.

Also, the storyline and overworld is static, while individual level layout and most npcs are randomized. This has it's own plus and minuses. Each area has it's own lore and strategy which planning for is part of the game and you wouldn't be able to do as much for completely randomized dungeons. On the other hand, if you are like me and like to rush to your death and try as many classes as possible, replaying the same quests and areas can start getting a little boring. However the game has a lot of different content and several starting areas to help alleviate the tedium of replaying the same starting areas over and over for each character.

Really a must have for any roguelike fan, it does a lot of the traditional elements very well while bringing a lot of unique flavor and strategy of its own.
Best game eeeeever!

Been having trouble putting this game down - even though I've just picked up an Oculus Rift :)  Great value for money and enormous fun.  Only sour note for me is probably one that'll stop me playing the game (and certainly the expansion at this rate) - which is the silly fearscape" thing - often 10-20 hours of work down the toilet in a few seconds :("

Absolutely yes! One of the best roguelikes i've ever played, and I've played many of them. Every character feels unique since they can be deeply customized. Part of its awesomeness stems from getting rid of those unfair deaths (lack of food, poisoned food, cursed items, out of depth monsters, undetectable deadly traps,etc) that are so frequent in other rogues (i'm looking at you stone soup), making every death your fault. steam doesn't properly track game time during offline mode, but i've played it for no less than 75 hours. I could spend the rest of my sunday trying to put into words how fascinating this game is, but unfortunately I've other issues to attend.

reviewText: As a Dungeon Master/fantasy writer, Tales of Maj'Eyal is great to have in the background to assist in the prevention of writers block.\n\nAs a fan of old school PC RPG's, Tales of Maj'Eyal is an intelligent throwback well worth the price of admission.
Great game, will keep you entertained for hundreds of hours.

Massive amount of content. Tons of unlockables. Great character customization. Immensely strategic turn based combat. Retro graphics. Fans of classic games like Exile and Avernum will enjoy this game immensley. Permadeth mode best of all!\n\nSo after a year of playing and almost 200 hours put into the game, I feel secure adding some more comments about the game. I can say, hands down, that this game is AMAZING! There is an unbelievable amount of content and lore that only keeps growing due to an active modding community and DLC from Dark God. I'm still discovering new, unexplored, areas of the game. I haven't even unlocked all the character creation paths yet. Best of all is the difficulty of this game. Any boss encounter will prove to be a challange, every encounter will become one if you raise the difficulty at all. One word of warning, this game is ADDICTIVE. I literally haven't been able to put it down since the DLC was released. Each class feels completely different. The only true drawback of the game is it's UI. At times the interface can be difficult. Some actions, escpecially in the inventory, take to many key strokes to accomplish. The menu hot keys are oddly selected too. Item information is displayed in a pretty hard to look at format. It seems the game's interface was designed with the keyboard in mind and not the mouse. The item filters need to be more specific. Being able to view the items based on armor type or weapon class would be handy. The hotbars get pretty confusing torwards the end of the game, when your character starts having more abilities than theres convinient room on the hotbar. Two, or more, active hotbars could alleviate this a little. It definitely takes some getting used to to become adept at interfacing with the game efficiently. Overall though, I would give this game the highest marks on content, lore, gameplay, and challenge!
Good game, free on dev's site. te4.org\nBought it on steam to unlock a special dual shield stone warden" class and give the dev some well deserved cash."

To get straight to the point, ToME is easily the best roguelike I've ever played. It has depth, variety, multiple difficulty settings, and has just the right balance between skill and luck. If you learn the game and know it well, you can handle even terrible situations with good play...but there's still never a time where you feel perfectly safe. This is still a roguelike after all, getting OHKOd from outside of your sight range by an overpowered rare monster is always on the table.

Pros:
Classes with unique and interesting skillsets. And a LOT of them.
Interesting races, also with uniqueness.
Large and skilled modding community, always writing new addons for the game.
A dev that listens to feedback!

Cons:
This game is long, and you'll want to play it multiple times if you get into it. Huge timesink.
No matter how many bugs DarkGod manages to get out of the code, there are always more. Some of them can end a run.
One of the more addicting games i've played, even with it's simplicity. It's also got plenty of secrets hidden under it's surface.

NOTE: This review has been modified since posting. It was originally posted in January 2015 as ‘negative’, and is from March 2015 onwards rated as ‘positive.’ In addition, the content has been altered to reflect recent changes to the game.
First of all, know that this is not a ‘rogue-lite’. I have yet to see the final level, and there are others on the forums who have played for hundreds of hours and have yet to win the game.
For the TL;DR people: The game is amazing, but completing it on normal difficulty will take hundreds of hours because the learning curve is steep, and end-game balance depends on creating the most powerful build you can – theory crafting is a must, and if you don’t, the game will become unwinnable 30 hours before you realize it. For the rest of us, read on.
ToME has 26 classes at the time of this writing, all of which feel and play very differently. Like most RPGs, skill points are gained upon leveling and can be used for both active and passive effects. The skills for each class are unique and allow players to develop their own playstyles, though generally each class has its own style of combat and a playstyle that rewards sticking to their class-specific strengths. Summoners draw hordes of creatures to overwhelm opponents, archmages channel elements to great effect over an area, and rogues set traps and use stealth to outmaneuver or outwit opponents. There are even more creative classes in here, like a time warden (or time mage) that specializes in temporal effects and paradoxes.
The world has tons of surprises and interesting levels/areas to explore, acceptable story and interaction (for an old-school roguelike) and though nothing ever changes, the vast variety of mechanics assured that the game did not get old for me after 100 hours of gameplay, and likely will not for another 100 hours.
But Tales of Maj’Eyal does have its problems. The first and perhaps least bothersome is a learning curve that feels more like a cliff than a slope.
The tutorial explains a little of the game's mechanics, but understanding is better gained by blundering through the world and slowly learning what each of the many confusing formulas and statistics mean, and how important they are to the core gameplay. It takes dedication to keep coming back when mountains of unknown skills and abilities assail you from every side, and through trial-and-error, learn to slowly overcome that mountain. Perseverance does pay off – I actually enjoyed the game very much once I crossed the barrier between hopeless bungler and still-hopeless-but-educated noob.
The larger problem is that in order to win the game, the player’s character must be designed for perfection – built to optimal capacity with a full understanding of the many talents, stat formulas, status effects and saving throws present in the game engine. It’s not enough just to go with the most damage, or discover the best damage reduction, or center your build around strategic options – you must do all of these things, and do them with the dedication of a crazed League of Legends professional gunning for the gold.
This is where the game fell apart previously –it can become unwinnable very early on, and new players will never even know. They may even feel overpowered for a while, as they make one-strike KOs against hordes of enemies and pass tens of dungeons without a serious challenge in any of them. Rares, elites, and bosses fall without challenge - then suddenly, a belligerent abomination of a boss-class monstrosity strikes, and they find themselves hopelessly outmatched, their only recourse to grind for levels.
So they go to a new dungeon – and it happens again. Another new dungeon – wait, were the normals this hard before? And why can’t I use my spells? My abilities? Where did everyone go? And… how did I get one-shot by THAT?
Players be warned: No matter how many lives you have, you can make a mistake in your character build early on and not realize that your character is doomed until late-game, when you have already invested thirty-or-more hours into their development. With permadeath, obviously, you may not live long enough to realize your character build is impossible to win with. But even with unlimited lives, you will eventually reach the point where the bosses are impossible, and no matter how well you fight, how clever your tactics, you have no option but to die – or quit. Before the 1.3.0 update, this meant that you must start the game over again from the beginning.
This is why my review changed from negative to positive. While limited and full-permadeath players will still have to deal with the intense frustrations of sub-optimal builds, there is hope for those playing with unlimited lives after the 1.3.0 update: Full talent re-spec is available at all times, so if you’ve created a build that seems sub-optimal to your playstyle or eventually becomes self-defeating, you can easily change your skills to accommodate your newfound knowledge or equipment. Be warned, however, that stat points and category points are still permanent, so consider playing a Cornac (+1 cat points) your first time and keeping some stat points in reserve for future use while you learn the ins and outs of your chosen class.
Also, be warned that there is no way to carry multiple save files for your character in this game. The game will save on entering and exiting a dungeon, as well as upon making most major decisions, and you will have to live with the consequences of your actions.
So to recap: Tales of Maj'Eyal as it is an interesting game that supports a wide variety of skill sets and play styles, though impressive knowledge of the game mechanics that can only be acquired through vigilant study required to develop a successful playstyle. Full talent re-spec alleviates (but not eliminates) the steep learning curve, but if you like RPG roguelikes with unique classes and deep strategy, investing your time in this game will reward you with probably the best roguelike you’ve ever played. Just be prepared to invest heavily.
*Full disclosure here - I played the game on 'normal' difficulty for every playthrough. There is an easier difficulty that decreases the monsters' strength/abilities by 30%, but it does not give classes, races or achievements and so it does not appeal to those like me who want to feel they are accomplishing something while playing.

This game is weird, a good weird, the sort where you can call on aid from a future version of yourself, and where the demons have a space platform in orbit over the world. And that's just scratching the surface, there are a ton of different classes that can each play in very different ways, from killing people with the power of hatred to triple weilding swords by holding the third with your mind, to a summoner who can generate energy swords, and so on. My only real complaint with the game is that I haven't had time to play more of it.

I've been playing roguelikes since I was a kid, starting with Rogue and Nethack, and over the years, I always come back to them. Maj'Eyal is a TRUE roguelike in a genre filled with (cough Diablo) wannabes saturated with good graphics and not much else. It's what I wished roguelikes were like when I was a kid. I love all the content that exists for this game.\n
Great game with a few funny derps in logic for example a character can kill 10-15 level 35 enemies when they are level 20 but die to 5 level 25 enemies at level 21

This game is a paragon of the rouguelike RPG genre. Between its engaging combat system abundance of optional lore wide variety of races and classes it channels D&D to create a compelling experience. I would claim with total confidence that this is up there as one of the most worthwile games on steam to sink your money and time into.
One of the very best traditional roguelikes you will find.

A game for anyone who likes rogue-like games. Just as addictive as the old style games but with one downside: Every item you find is identified for you and a mouse-over reveals strengths and weaknesses of visible enemys.\n\nI played nearly all of the rogue-style games and this one is enjoyable and a wonderful waste of time.

reviewText:
At over 100 hours played at this point I can safely say I haven't even beaten normal mode yet.  Haven't really tried easy due to the fact I can't unlock anything on easy mode.  Sure, content wise there's a week less of campaign time although there's also 2 different gameplay modes to unlock if you get bored of that (arena and an infinite dungeon mode) and there's over 100 different class/race combos to try out.  The thing that got me to buy the game though (yeah, you can play for free, just google the game) is the steam achievements.  Seriously, what other game has over 1300 achievements???

If you're an achievement junkie, this game will safely occupy your time for at least 500 hours (it's looking like it's going to be a lot more for me) and if not, it's still a super fun game that will challenge you even at the lowest of difficulties.  I haven't even tried to play arena or infinite dungeon yet, I'm still just trying to beat normal mode and like I started this review with, I've played over 100 hours.


10/10, better time sink than WoW ever was.

Really great game. I wasn't too sure about it when I bought it, but it turned out to be better than I could ever hope for. No matter how many times I get ran over by archers and mages I always end up coming back to it.

Fun seemingly simple rpg.

It seems if you like hard or easy rpg games, this game accomadates you easily.

The further you achieve with a character before it dies, will unlock further stuff for your next character. For instance: I killed a certain boss character, and it gave me a transmorgrification box for the rest of my plays. Another example is that when I reached level 10 (i think), it unlocked a new character class for my next characters.

It had me playing for hours, and still wanting to come back and play some more.

This game is a masterpiece. The game is incredibly fun, has many different possible playstyles, builds, classes, races, modes, and an incredibly high replay value. The story is great, the art is great, the gameplay is great, the music is great, this game is great all around! If you like any roguelike, specifically any tile based roguelike, you are going to really enjoy this game. It's not even that expensive of a game! Support the creators of this game and go get it! Watch out, though. This game can get difficult.
play this game!

Wasn't expecting much from this game, but I can see myself sinking countless hours into it.  Expertly handcrafted roguelike that will having you coming back for more.  Amazing amount of character customization coupled with engauging lore will keep me coming back for more.  Well done man!

The best roguelike game that I have ever played. Very unique and lots of fun.

I reluctantly recommend this game due to its sheer addictiveness. I did not want to get addicted to it, but it sucks you in. One more character, one more level. It makes you want to understand it, to learn, to improve... and then you lose another character you've spent half a day on, and start a new one. I am not proud of the time I've been spending on this game, but it's like digital crack.
